reviewText:
Designed to offer its user hours of entertainment, Empire TV Tycoon is a game that tells the player to get people in front of their screens, while the game has that very same effect on the player. It’s hard to know when it’s time to stop.

Television is a medium of entertainment which permits millions of people to listen to the same joke at the same time, and yet remain lonesome.

T.S. Eliot

Without any further delay, I present to you my review of Empire TV Tycoon.

GameplayThe game gives the player a simple goal: to be the best channel.

As you learn the basics, you’ll soon discover that being the best doesn’t always mean having the best programs, or the best comercials deals, or the most cashflow. Sometimes, it doesn’t even mean having the highest audience.

To be the best - and to win the game - the player needs to achieve a certain number of points, “Fame” as they’re called. These points are obtained each time block, depending on the game mode, as well as your channel’s position when compared to the rival channels. Simply put, the channel with the highest audience wins the most points. However, points can also be obtained by winning some awards, with cerimonies happening every two days, and the player can choose to participate by submitting a movie, self-produced, of a certain genre. Not only are these awards a good source of Fame points, they’re also a good revenue source.

Now, here’s where the real fun, and management starts. There are eight kinds of audience, and twelve program genres - thirteen if you count “Live Events”, so, as you can easily guess, not everyone likes the same programs.

However, you must also consider the overall picture when you have more than one kind of audience in a time block, which means you’ll have to find the best suitable program for all of them to like, or at least have a positive likeability average.

Once you’ve used a program - there are four different types - it loses its freshness, meaning you won’t be able to use it, at least not efficiently, anytime soon. This is where the actual managament comes in to play, as you’ll have to juggle between what is available to you, what the vendor has and what your scriptwriters/production office can put out. Let’s not forget the pirate copies, but piracy is wrong, right?

To help you get more viewers, you can use some marketing features, of which there’s a total of five available to you. This will help you to get that tiny, tiny number of extra viewers you need to finish that one ugly commercial contract you need to comply with, unless you want the penalty hammer to come down on you.

Producing your own programs can be very good, or very bad. Some can be quite expensive, and unless the resources are properly distributed, you might end up with a poor program, while a better one could have, most likely, been obtained for a much cheaper price at the vendor.

As the player’s Fame points increase, new upgrades for the channel will be made available, from an improved movie library, to a wider broadcast, and even better actors, they’re all very good, and important to get that extra edge.

Running a TV channel is a hard thing, and doing it alone is even harder, and that’s exactly why you can hire up to four workers to help you. This sounds extremely sweet, until you’re faced with the available options, all of which have their advantages. As the Rolling Stones have said many, many times, “You can’t always get what you want.”

Who would have thought that something that looks so simple could, in fact, be so complex?

I almost forgot. References! There’s a bucketload of references in the game. From movies to series and even music. I found myself giggling a couple times due to them.

What to expectTrue to its description, Empire TV Tycoon allows the player to manage their own channel, competing with other channels in order to be the one with the highest audience.
From setting the correct program genre to the correct audience, or by choosing the best available, taking into consideration the blocks available, as well as the freshness of the program, it’s up to the player to run a successful channel.
I’d also like to mention that the development team was, and still is, very interested in improving the game, and making sure it’s what everyone expects it to be, and more, while quickly fixing some errors.

What not to expectUnless you misread the description, or someone gave you the wrong idea, do not expect the game allow you to build your own office, or set up your own studio or set special contracts with actors.

VerdictWorth Purchasing. With a couple changes and a few additions, the Empire TV Tycoon has all it takes to be the best within the sub-genre, for years to come. Don’t be surprised to see my verdict change as new features are added.

NoteFor those that want some sort of comparison, imagine Mad TV with a much more appealing look, as well as an extremely engaging atmosphere.

reviewText:
I love tycoon and simulation games, but I just can't recommend this game at this time.

The premise is good and the core design works, so there's potential in my opinion.  But here are the reasons I've quit playing for now:

-Viewership seems to be genre based only (and some of it doesn't make sense).  The plot and other aspects of the show mean nothing.  Lovers don't like Sports movies.  So if you program a sports movie for them, they won't tune in, even though it's a love story too.   I haven't seen a change in Elderly viewership based on when the movie was made.  The elderly don't like comedies, but they wouldn't tune in for a Laurel and Hardy movie?  And what's up with guys not liking comedies?

-Multi-hour films have no effect on viewership.  A huge audience of lovers will watch the first hour of a romance film, then just leave in the middle of it.  A geek will sit down to watch a 3 hour Sci-Fi film after 2/3s of it is over.  Good marketing should bring in viewers early.  A good film should keep some viewers engaged for its duration.

-The necessity of moving to different parts of the building is annoying to me.  I get that it's part of the time-management mechanism, but when I am browsing ads or movies, I'd really like to see my schedule and the viewers for upcoming time slots. As it stands, you have to memorize your day's schedule to make the trip to the other floor productive.  My guy doesn't have a PDA or a printer he can use to take the schedule to the movie vault with him?

-Purchased advantages give no advantage.  The developers acknolwedge this in the forums.  When you buy tech from Doc Brown, the AI players get it at the exact same time.  So there's no advantage to purchasing them.  The developers state they may change this, but by doing so will either make the fame game extremely hard (when the AI gets tech and you don't) or easy (when you get it but the AI doesn't have the fame yet.)  This leads into the next item.

-Tech jumps are far too steep.  When I got the 'streaming' tech recently, my viewership jumped massively.   It's such a steep change, all the ads in your queue that haven't had a block filled are removed from your list, and those that you can finish are ridiculously easy.  There needs to be more upgrades to purchase that provide smaller boosts.  It would add to the strategy of the game, while diminshing the tech gap issue in the previous item.

One of the tech gap issues revolves around the library of available films.  If you get the tech that gives you higher rated movies and your opponent doesn't, you could really outpace them on fame.  This is why when you get it, the AI gets it too.  It's a dumb mechanism.

So with all the flaws, I'll be putting this game on the back shelf for a while.

reviewText:
You can never have too many good tycoon games on Steam, and this is a very nice one by a new small developer.

Pros
+ Charming art style
+ The premise of being one of 3 competing tv channels is nice, keeps you on your toes and stops the endgame from turning into just watching the money roll in from unknown sources.
+ Plenty of features and things to keep an eye on: managing your tv schedule, producing your own shows, special tv events, employee management etc.
+ Full of pop culture references and some genuine laugh out loud moments
+ Stable game, haven't experienced any major bugs or crashes
+ Fast and frequent updates and support from the developers

Cons
- No Endless Mode (yet)
- UI is a bit too responsive at times, for example deleting an email can make your character run around aimlessly. A minor annoyance at worst but it's there.
- A bit more information about the underlying features would be nice. Sometimes it seems even a perfectly planned out program chart leads to 2nd or 3rd in the ratings with no obvious reason why.
- Some programs don't fit their respective genres or audience groups. Children like Brother Bear and The Last Legion just as much, and Elders like Nymphomaniac simply because it's a Drama.
- Men don't like Masters of the Universe. -1 for realism.

Overall, the game has a lot of bang for the buck. Plenty of features and replayability already, and with future updates it should have even more so. If you're a fan of Mad TV or tycoon games in general, I highly recommend you pick this one up.

Empire TV Tycoon was developed and published by Dreamsite Games. It was released on October 20th, 2015 for $12.99. A press review copy was provided for The Hidden Levels.

Empire TV Tycoon is a unique member of the tycoon family style of games. It is inspired by Mad TV and Game Dev tycoon according to it’s development team and I agree with that statement wholeheartedly. The first session I played after knowing the full scope of the game was extremely addictive and fun. The aspect of managing the marketing and advertising for best viewership is challenging and though provoking. My station produced many movies and TV shows, and won awards for them. You do this all by hiring writers, actors, and production assistants to help your cause.

What I enjoyed:

Management time – My first completed game for 300 fame felt like it took an hour and a half or so. I was streaming live at the time and as it happens it was closer to four hours of non-stop TV station management. It’s always a good sign when I can lose myself in a game, clicking and planning was more pleasant than I initially expected. The option to speed the game up only gives you a slight push as you’ll need to stop and film new movies or shows, deal with viewer requests, and update your library. Each day adds new challenges that cause the player to adapt their strategy often.

Culture shock – The amount of cultural references (mostly pop culture) in Empire Tv Tycoon is borderline obscene, which is perfect. You buy your movies from one of two iconic characters, Walter white from Breaking Bad is the legal seller, and Silent Bob from Jay and Silent Bob sells the bootleg goods. You buy your ads from Mad Men’s Don Draper, your tech upgrades from Back to the Future’s Doc Brown.. The level of detail to mainstream television is absolutely perfect, this aspect helped sell the entire theme very well.

Reruns – The replay value here is astronomical, you can play an arcade mode to a set number of fame, or play endless mode and see just how far you can take your station over lengthy campaigns. There are a number of various events which give each replay a fresh feel. Producing movies and TV shows to compete in various awards shows also changes from game to game so you never know what you’ll be producing next.

What I disliked:

Information request – The biggest flaw with my experience was that certain genres seem to miss certain viewers that aren’t always logical. I programmed the Sopranos for a one hour block with male viewers to complete a male targeted car advertisement and they not only didn’t hit the numbers but turned their TV to another station. I did fins that fantasy movies were good for kids, and sci-fi good for nerds, but there should be some way to track what genres are working with certain viewers.

See it to believe it – The portion of the game where you have scripts written, hire actors, and film productions is fantastic. The problem I have with it is that you get a numerical rating afterwards and little else. It would be an amazing addition to see some scenes from that movie or show, or see your product in a form other than a numerical rating. This is more of a wishful addition than a complaint, but I often felt that my station worked hard to make the movie, we should get to see at least a funny scene from it or something of that nature.

This was a surprising review for me because at first glance I was somewhat apprehensive to play Empire TV Tycoon. The tycoon style of game often feels bland or boring for my taste but this game really is quite enjoyable. The pop culture references made me giggle often through my game, and certain film or TV shows displayed in the game are childhood favorites. Theme is important and this game delivers it in droves, you’ll really feel engaged and challenged while trying to run your station. For me this was a clear reminder not to judge a game by it’s cover, as this game is an instant favorite in my library.

Score: Buy it now

This game is a simple amalgation of MadTV and M.U.D. TV. From MUD they have taken the social groups and the rest from MadTV. But is it fun? Yes,yes it is. It is an awesome take on that game and if you liked MadTV, you will like this one.

You turn every script in either a TV Show with multiple episodes, a TV Film (1 hour) a standard movie (2 hours) or a Blockbuster (3 hours). You then need to distribute points, which kind of works like in GameDev Tycoon. An action movie benefits more from special effects, than e.g. a Drama. So you need to find out the best combinations, which adds some depth to it.

Overall, I really like the game.

reviewText:
Empire TV Tycoon is an easy to learn fun simulation where you run a tv channel.

As you increase viewership and make those important decisions on what to play and what ads to show, you can climb the ranks from a simple local channel to the world of satellite broadcasting.

Part of the game is programming your day's viewing - which sounds more tedious or daunting than it actually is.

You will recognise some movie titles, and the spoofs of well-known award shows and film festivals. This adds to the immersive side of Empire, and it can be quite fun (if not diabolical) to plan a day's tv viewing based on your favourite films... or least favourites...

You can hire staff, including a scriptwriter which is pretty key if you intend to do the optional portion of entering the aforementioned film festivals and award shows. The scripts themselves don't really make sense, which is a bit of a shame overall, and you end up just looking at the script rating before deciding to tear it up (with the rather satisfying sound effect) or keeping it to make the film.

Making films is pretty straight forward, as you have a studio floor where you hire stars (spoofs of actual stars or iconic movie characters) and decide on the format for your script - tv movie, tv series, feature big budget, etc. You can enter these films in the festivals and then sell them later on after you've screened them on your channel.

You can fill the world with John Waters tributes, or cringe-worthy game shows. Or Meryl Streep performances - the world is your oyster. You call the shots.

Overall gameplay is simple - after my second play through I had already won" the default game

reviewText:
I was lucky enough to get a code from the developer to test out the game a few days before launch. That night I stayed up until 3am playing it.  It's definitely one of THOSE kinds of games.

It plays a lot like a cross between Game Dev Tycoon, The Movies, Sim Tower and few other classic tycoon games. It's got a very charming art style and sound design to go with it. Lots of brillaint audio and visual cues play out to keep you constantly aware of what's going on as the game progresses.

A playthrough roughly lasts about 3-4 hours and there's easily a lot of re-playability here with a few different difficulty options available and a competing AI to keep you on your feet.

I really like a lot of what this game has to offer and was incredibly impressed with it from the get go, there's an interesting level of challenge in place as you try to figure out the best show/blocking combination based on the audience that's watching and what your best opportunity is to make money from advertisements at the end of each block. I was constantly trying to figure out if I shoul aim my ads at a specific group that's currently watching, or save that slot for later when I might get more views. Games like this really excel from learning curves, it's what makes them great. I failed my first game, I knew fairly early on that I wasn't doing amazingly but I wanted to continue to get to grips of all the systems.  There's a good amount of information delivered to you in tutorials, but the game doesn't hold your hand too much and encourages you to experiment with it and I really respect that in games like this.

I think the only real problem is that the game could benefit from a continue option once the game is over. (Though I think that's coming in a later update). There's something about just trying to fill and programme your schedule that's addictive enough, I didn't really mind that I'd lost and wanted to continue doing that. So just be aware that at the minute once it's game over, you have to start again.

It's games like this that make you realise just how brilliant the indie scene can be when a developer really loves their product and tries to make something fun and interesting, it really shows. So if you're like me and love tycoon games or any of the games mentioned above I'm sure it's something you'll also enjoy and I'd highly recommend picking it up.

reviewText:
This game is pretty faithful reimagining of Mad TV (the classic underappreciated DOS game) with a lot of fun improvements and a modern interface.

As opposed to a couple of the negative reviews I've read here, I quite enjoyed the element of having to cater to a varying audience throughout the day. It adds a bit of a puzzle and fast-thinking element to the game, and I feel if you could just choose one particular audience type the game would be far too easy, since you'd only have to worry about one type of show and ignore everything else. The whole point is to build a library of shows and movies for a diverse audience and try to grab the largest market share possible away from the competition.

If you're wondering why the competing stations are in the same building as you, it's because that's exactly how Mad TV worked. It creates some interesting and frantic situations where they can block you from getting to a destination in time, buy a movie or take an ad contract before you, or you can do the same to them. You can see the competing program directors scrambling around just like you, and it's helps foster a little bit of rivalry feeling as you pass them in the halls. I believe, also, that the developer has said something about sabotage in a future update (which was also in Mad TV), so you'd need to be able to visit competitors' offices and such to do so.

The tutorial could probably use a little work, but because I had played Mad TV before, and the game works basically the same way, I'm not exactly sure if I am the best judge of that. The game has a few rough edges here and there, such as a couple of typos in movie descriptions, but overall the polish is pretty solid for a small indie team of 2 people.

Overall, I'd say this game is easily worth its modest price, especially if there are a few more add-ons in the plans.

You will manage the content-production, advertising & programming of a TV station. Sound easy? It kinda is. It does take awhile to get the hang of it and once you do understand the game there is still information you will never know (see annoyances). Overall I enjoyed EmpireTV because of the rewarding feeling you get from building the resources of your TV company.

Annoyances: It's not always clear what audience segments will tune in, and even if you do know who is watching it isn't clear what programming they prefer. The success of a programming slot feels random. The most annoying thing is the advertising requirements. There is simply no indicator as to how many audience members will tune in - ie. will the advertisement fail or not? So you naturally go for the safe option earning the minimum. And they have recently patched the game so getting perfect 10s are impossible unless you get the correct lucky popups (but I can live with that).

Empire TV Tycoon is a recommended when on sale.

reviewText:
The title went from being 'meh', to being something I can sink the occasional hour or two into thanks to the developers having expanded on the content and game play to include mod support, where I can modify the actors and movies, to include custom images.

Game play wise, it has a few things that I find a little annoying.

1. Your ai opponents aren't restricted to the same measurements that you are, where you can only do certain things once you've reached a certain level of fame, I noticed that the ai was more or less using my fame level to determine what they could obtain and do. Such as placing antennaes for expanding your audience, and the higher quality movie library.
2. Get used to the option to speed up time. Without it, you'll feel like you're watching paint dry.

The first one is a big annoyance, the second one is more a warning to use the buttons to speed things up if it seems like it's mind numbingly slow.

If you're looking for pro's - here's a few.
1. You can make your own tv series or movies. You do it by hiring a script writer. They make a script that has a certain quality, you can give it a title of your choosing, then you can hire two actors (lead and supporting), and then produce it where you assign production points to topics in order to try and influence the movie quality.
2. You've a variety of staff you can hire. Max you can hire four staff members from what I noticed, although there are more than four 'jobs' - so choosing the four types that you hire is a strategy based on your play approach.
3. It's intersting trying to find content that meets certain viewing groups desires, although some groups are defintely easier to please than others. Alone, you can quickly figure out what they like, but when you've 3 groups together, such as kids, elders, and rockers, and suddenly finding something they'll all tune in for gets a bit trickier.
4. It's not rocket science. I'd say it's a step past casual and just short of complex in regards to figuring out what you need to do in order to be semi-successful.

reviewText:
I saw this game during the Wintersale on Steam and it caught my attention, looking like the old Mad-TV, a game that i play even today sometimes.
During the years, there were a lot of bad clones, none of them ever reached the playability of the original.

After playing it around 14 hours, i can say that this is the best clone of MTV to date, and it is not just a clone, it has some ideas on its own.
It is not perfect, but if you liked the old MTV, you should give it a try.

So what is the difference?

You have to plan you Movies based on a specific group of viewers. Women like Romance Movies, Kids like Fantasy and so on. Showing movies to the wrong audience results in lesser viewers and a bad reputation.

It is not realistic, that you have to plan your Movie Schedule based on the Viewers at a specific time. But nonethenless, it gives the game a nice twist. In the old MTV, you simply put the best movies you could get in your Schedule, and the viewers watch whatever you show. Now you have to think hard how you can satisfy Elders, Women and Kids at the same time. I like that.

Here are some things, i dont like:
Betty Botterblum is gone. Ok, i always ignored her until i had enough money to buy the gifts. But without her, something is missing. Also, the hoaxes you could play the other opponents are gone. No elevator signs you can change.
No Boss, no office.
Overall,this wasnt so important, but it added some atmosphere.
No antennas. You upgrade directly to satellite. (Will be changed in future update)
The Animations are bad also, the original is far better.
No Live Footage, like superbowl. Ok, sometimes you can send a small live newsreport, but getting big sport events on my channel were always a highlight in MTV.

Good:
Movie Production and Rating for the competition. Having points that you can distribute around the movie production is cool. That make you really feel a little like a producer. Would be cool it this feature will be enhanced.
Advertising and employees.
The gameflow is good and you can custumize the game.
Quests. But instead of rewarding with money which is unrealistic (why does my mother pay 400K that i show a movie??), you should have other advantages (or avoid disadvantages).

I could write more, but i prefer to play it now ;-)
So, if you like Mad-TV, give Empire-TV a chance.

I figured the game out quickly and was able to be the number one channel. I think as the game updates, it will be more interesting. But this type of game is only good for about an hour or so. The awards are another plus. The award shows are awesome. It encouraged me to keep making my own shows/films and I would feel great when I won.

Overall I would still recommend this game. I thought it was fun for about an hour, but that's it. I am sure once the game progresses in updates it will be even more awesome. I would give it a 3.5/5.

I had high expectations for this game. I've enjoyed Tycoon games ever since I were a kid. The concept itself is amazing. Running a TV company! I fell in love with it after playing Game Dev Tycoon. The problem is I fell in love with it over advertisement. I got a steam card for christmas and bought this! After 20 minutes of playing I realized this is not as good as other Tycoon games. I jumped in and the tutorial confused the crap out of me. After playing for about 20 minutes I immediately requested a refund from Steam. This game should NOT be getting good reviews!

Pros
--------
*Amazing Idea
*Nice Variety

Cons
--------
*Difficult to learn
*Tutorial sucks
*Elevator takes forever to take you around
*Can't make own company or CHARACTER!? (More on this below)
*VERY.VERY.Tedious

This game is extremely tedious. I feel like time goes really fast. I truly wish there was a way to pause time in this game. I'm trying to plan a schedule and it's going by way too fast! Also why do you share a building with your rivals? It sucks, because they are constantly moving up and down stealing the elevator from you. Oh my god the elevator. This thing is slower than an elderly lady going backwards on escalator.

I also think it's stupid how you can't make your own character or company! Why on Earth can you not do this? They give you 3 generic companies to take over. I wish you had 3 rival companies, so you can create your own. Games like Game Dev Tycoon give you the freedom to make your own character and company. It makes you feel like an individual. What's the point of giving us a choice? It's either generic company 1, generic company 2, or Walter White. I know it's not a big deal, but it will pisses me off how you can't create your own company or character.

If you're reading this, then try Game Dev Tycoon. It's not a TV studio, but it's a game making studio. It's extremely fun and addictive. Trust me. I would rather buy game dev tycoon a second time, than buy this game (Since I got a refund).

Tl;dr: Good Concept turned into a terrible tedious and confusing game.

It could have been so much better. (TL; DR at the bottom)

You schedule programs (during the same day people are to be watching them!) based on knowing what type of people (rockers, elders, et cetera) will watch it? Shoulden't it be that you schedule programs weeks in advance, and that you get viewers based on what you air?

Your ads should reach a set percentage of viewers? Shouldn't it be a set amount of viewers? Upgrading your antenna, making you reach more viewers, just makes you have to show the ad to more people without getting a bigger reward. What is the advantage? (EDIT: Simply put,after having played this game for almostr 15 hours, I still don't understand the mechanics involved.)

You play in an environment with two other companies, sharing an elevator, but you can't play multiplayer? (This will be added in later, says a developer)

The formula for which audiece groups likes which shows is not random for each game, meaning it is possible to make a chart and use it to schedule the best shows for the given audience groups. Which means that 1. you learn this eventually and 2. replayability suffers greatly. (EDIT: you can change this in settings, apparently) It would be better if this info was given from the start, in-game, and your job was to try to air shows that will cater to as many audience groups as possible while getting your ads contracts done. Also, you could try to cater more to certain groups, and thus getting acces to special shows and events, while accepting that you have a smaller viewer base and thus get less money from ads.

TL; DR--> this game is totally backwards. I cannot recommend it.

Now Listen, Before We Begin I Want Everyone Reading This To Know, That I Strongly Believe This Game Has STRONG Potential. I Will Be Listing The Pros And Cons Of This Game So I Can Give You A In Depth Look Into The Game Before You Buy It.

Pros:
1. Good Concept

2. The Game Uses Real Life TV Channel Names, Movies, And TV Shows Which In My Opinion Makes The Game Even Better.

3. It Gives You A Good idea Of What Happens Behind The Scenes Of TV Channels. (Showing How Hard It Is To Run A TV Channel)

4. Controls Are Excellent, Point And Click

Plenty More, Except I Don't Have Time To List All Of Them.

Cons:
MAIN PROBLEM: There Is No Sandbox Mode. There Is No Mode Where You Can Play For Fun And Retry If Your Studio Turns Out Bad, Like Other Tycoon Games Like Game Dev Tycoon. This Game Feels Like A Party Game Where You Have A Set Amount Of Time To Complete Something That Takes More Time Than You Have. If This Game Implemented A Gamemode Where You Could Play with No Deadline, This Game Would Be Fine, And I Would Come Back Here And Instantly Change This Review To A Positive One. - Dreamsite Games, For God Sake Add One, I Believe In You.

Also Im Going To Say This, I Do Not Believe You Should Refund This Game Either, I Think They Will Fix This Game And Make It A Fun And Enjoyable Experience.

1. Confusing As All Hell When Your First Starting Off.
(The Tutorial Helps Very Little, It Takes You Through In One Go, No Going Back.)

2. Theres No One Telling You What To Do (Which Can Be Helpful) While Your Playing. You Have To
Figure Out What To Do And Find Strategys On Your Own. (Which Some People May Enjoy, I Don't... Sadly)

3. The Amount Of Time It Takes To Be Able To Show The Same Movie Or TV Show Again. I Found Myself In Situations Where I Had To Buy A Whole Bunch Of TV Shows And Movies And Not Being Able To Buy Any ADS Or Marketing To Go Along With Them Without Going Bankrupt. I Needed To Sell Loved TV Series/Movies Just To Help My Company Stay Alive.

4. Kinda Goes Along With My Tutorials Problem, But I Feel Like There Is A Lack Of Information Telling You How To Do Something? I Found Myself Not Even Using The Tools I Was Given, Such As The TV At The Bottom Right, Useless In My Opinion.

5. It Is VERY, And I Mean VERY Hard To Get Started And Run A Successful Studio. I Was Buying Ads That I Wasn't Able To Reach The Requirements For, Which Made Me Go Bankrupt. Like Who Am I Trying To Please? The Damn Nazi's?

Once Again, Im Sure Theres More, But Sadly Im lazy.

Final Views: This Game, I Was Actually Excited For. As Soon As I Got Home From Classes, I Got Straight On Steam And Bought This Game. Overall, After Playing For A Good 45 Minutes, I Got Bored, And Felt Sad That This Game Didn't Turn Out How I Thought It Would. I See A Bright Future For This Game, But Sadly Right Now, Not So Much.

Goodluck Dreamsite Games.
